Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Neuroendocrine basis of gestural display evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
The signals that animals use for reproductive communication are vital for survival and progeny, and thus the evolution of such signals is extensively studied. Yet, despite this work, little is known about signal evolution from a physiological perspective, particularly with respect to how the nervous system is changed to support the emergence of novel signals. To address this issue, this research project investigates the mechanisms underlying an unusual reproductive communication signal in frogs, known as the "foot flag." By comparing how androgenic hormones, such as testosterone, act on the spinal cord and hind limb muscles in foot-flagging vs. non foot-flagging frogs, this project aims to understand what changes occurred as foot-flagging evolved in this species group. This project also applies physiological models that have explained motor disease to understanding the evolution of this complex and ecologically relevant behavior. Results provide insight into how neural systems can evolve and function in the natural environment. Additionally, the unique collaboration between researchers at a women's college, a research university, and the world-class Vienna Zoo provide hands-on research experiences for 1st and 2nd year undergraduates, particularly women and first-generation college students. The investigators also incorporate this research into undergraduate courses and fund international research experiences that include public outreach about the biology and conservation of foot-flagging frogs in Borneo, India, and Peru.

This project uses a comparative approach and combines molecular and behavioral analyses to test how the action of androgenic hormones is modified in neuromotor systems to support the evolution of new reproductive communication signals. Prior data shows that the emergence of "foot flagging" in male frogs - a signal that is produced by conspicuously waving the hind limb - is marked by a 10-fold increase in the androgenic sensitivity within the skeletal muscles that control this movement. Using quantitative real-time PCR and in situ hybridization to compare androgen receptor levels in foot-flagging vs. non-foot flagging species, this research project tests the hypothesis that changes in expression levels and patterning of androgen receptors within multiple levels of the hindlimb neuromotor pathway are associated with the independent evolution of foot flagging in multiple frog lineages. Furthermore, this project uses pharmacological tools to block androgen receptors in order to test the hypothesis that androgenic signaling in leg muscles is required for foot-flagging behavior and to support the spinal motor circuitry that controls hind limb movement. Though such "bottom up" modification of neuromotor circuitry is reported in studies of motor disease, this project is the first study to explore this as a mechanism for regulating a complex and ecologically relevant motor behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many animals use body movement, or gesture, to communicate with each other. Some of the most extreme examples of this phenomenon come from species that perform elaborate dance routines to court mates and/or compete with rivals during times of breeding. These traits are especially interesting from the perspective of motor control, because the movements involved in animal dance routines often push an animal to its performance limit.

Here, we study not only how hormone systems can evolve to transform animal motor control, but also how these transformations help animals to produce gestures that do not otherwise seem possible. We do this work in frogs that have evolved elaborate waving display to compete in breeding areas. Androgens like testosterone are key to the evolution of this signal, as the muscles that control it appear almost 10x more sensitive to testosterone that circulates in the bloodstream. Equally impressive is that this seems to be the case every time these waving display arise in a new frog species, even when the waving display emerges in frogs that live on opposite sides of the globe and that are separated by millions of years of evolution. This suggests that androgen-muscle interactions create a pathway for new gestures to arise during the course of evolution. Next, we address why androgens are so important to the evolution of gestures used for communication. We found that testosterone appears to act on muscles that control the display and cause them to make growth signals that travel back to the spinal cord. There, the growth signals make the neural cells that convey messages from the brain to the muscles become larger and more capable of generating fast limb movements. This mechanismsof "retrograde feedback" from the muscle to the nervous system a only been described in rodents used to study motor disease; thus, our studies are among the first to suggest that such mechanisms help regulate elaborate behavior. Moreover, our work implies that such mechanisms provide a common route by which new performance traits can evolve. These studies provide a significant advance to our understanding of the role the nervous and endocrine systems play in behavioral evolution. 

In addition to the research described above, our grant funded several important outreach projects. First, we included a wide range of undergraduate researchers into our research projects, many of whom came from historically underrepresented groups from around the USA. Second, our research program coordinated with other principal investigators to initiate laboratory exchanges, in which trainees learned from others at various career stages. Finally, we set up a modular science exhibit at the Vienna Zoo in Austria, which is renowned for breeding the waving frogs we used in our study. This exhibit illustrates the findings we produced, sharing them with hundreds of thousands of visitors each year from all over Europe and the rest of the world. Our exhibit introduces observers to fundamental concepts in behavior and neurobiology.
